intro: Leontodon pseudotaraxaci, commonly known as the false dandelion, is a perennial herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads made up of numerous small florets. The plant typically grows in meadows, grasslands, and woodland edges, preferring well-drained soils. Its leaves are basal, rough, and often have a hairy texture, while the flowers are yellow and resemble those of true dandelions. It is known for its ability to thrive in a variety of environmental conditions, making it a common sight in temperate regions.
